titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Vardis Fisher Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday March 5, 2019 at 04:03

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Vardis Fisher papers document the personal and professional life of prolific Western novelist and author Vardis Fisher.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Acquired through various gifts and purchases, 1958-1996.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Vardis Fisher Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Vardis Fisher Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The finding aid for this collection is compiled from individual preliminary lists for each acquisition that were created at or around the time of receipt by the library.

As a rule, descriptive information found in the Collection Contents section is drawn in large part from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.
Formerly classed as Za Fisher, Uncat Za Fisher, Uncat Za Ms 238, Uncat Za Ms 286, Uncat Za Ms 509, and Uncat Za Ms 594.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Portions of the collection also avaliable on microfilm. Consult Access Services for additional information.

bioghist.head: Vardis Fisher (1895-1968)
bioghist.p: Vardis Fisher was born March 31, 1895 in Annis, Idaho to Joseph Oliver and Temperance (Thornton) Fisher. He was educated at the University of Utah (A.B., 1920) and the University of Chicago (A.M., 1922 and Ph.D., 1925).

After graduating from the University of Chicago, Fisher taught for several years as an assistant professor of English at the University of Utah (1925-1928) and New York University (1928-1931) before returning to Idaho, where he served as director of the Federal Writers Project for the state of Idaho (1935-1939) and as an editor and contributor to various periodicals from the late 1930s until his death in 1968.

Fisher won a number of awards for his literary and non-fiction work, including the Harper Prize in 1939 for Children of God , the Wrangler Award for best Western historical novel in 1965 for Mountain Man , and the Spur Award in 1966 and 1969. Fisher's novel Mountain Man was made into a popular film ( Jeremiah Johnson ), starring Robert Redford, by Sydney Pollack in 1972.
Fisher married three times: to Leona McMurtrey, 1918; Margaret Trusler, 1928; and Opal Laurel Holmes, 1940.
Biographical information taken from "Vardis (Alvero) Fisher." Contemporary Authors Online . Detroit: Gale, 2003. Gale Biography In Context . Web. 7 Mar. 2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Vardis Fisher papers document the personal and professional life of prolific Western novelist and author Vardis Fisher. The collection contains material relating to writing projects, personal and family correspondence, photographs, financial records, and personal papers. Writings include notes for large projects, such as the multi-volume Testament of Man , as well as drafts, proofs, printed versions, and other materials for numerous novels, non-fiction, and shorter works dating from the mid 1930s onward. There are drafts and other materials, for example, for his successfull early novel Children of God (1939) to his late Suicide or Murder? (1962) , an analysis of the death of Meriwether Lewis. Personal correspondence includes incoming and outgoing letters with friends, writers, publishers, magazines, and others. Additional Fisher material includes financial records, clippings, and personal papers. There is also a fair amount of unsorted correspondence, Fisher family correspondence, Opal Fisher correspondence, and photographs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized chronologically by acquisition into five groupings: I. 1958-1968 Acquisitions, 1936-1962. II. August 1992 Acquisition, 1905-1990. III. June 1993 Acquisition, 1870-1984. IV. December 1996 Acquisition, [circa 1930s-1980s]. V. December 1998 Acquisition, [circa 1940s-1960s].

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two groupings: Writings and Correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains material relating to writing projects and correspondence. Writings include notes for large projects, such as the multi-volume Testament of Man , as well as drafts, proofs, and other materials for numerous novels, non-fiction, and shorter works dating from the mid 1930s onward. Correspondence consists of incoming and outgoing letters with friends, writers, publishers, magazines, and others, and includes unsorted material.
Former call number: Za Fisher.

did.unittitle: "A Reply to Dick Lake's Report on 'Forgive Us Our Virtues'"

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four subgroupings: Fisher Family Correspondence, Writings, Other Writings, and Miscellaneous.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains Fisher family correspondence, writings by and about Fisher, and personal papers.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 238.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased on the Eugene G. O'Neill Memorial Fund and Frederick W. and Carrie S. Beinecke Fund for Western Americana, 1992.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four groupings: Correspondence, Writings, Printed Material, and Photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains a small amount of additional correspondence and writings, as well as photographs of Fisher and members of the Fisher family and audio recordings.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 286.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from D'Archivists on the Sinclair Lewis and Donald Windham-Sandy Campbell Collection Endowment funds, 1993.

scopecontent.p: Opal talking to Steve, also to Sherry; dad talking about money; who is best for Opal; dad talking about going blind; bad bladder. Vardis is 70 on this tape. From V. Fisher to Grant Fisher.

did.unittitle: Tape from Vardis Fisher to son Grant; Opal on part

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains unsorted Vardis Fisher papers, including correspondence, writings, financial records, clippings, audiovisual material, and personal papers, as well as Opal Fisher correspondence and material about or relating to Fisher, such as shooting scripts and other material relating to the film Jeremiah Johnson , made after Fisher's death in 1972.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 509

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Grant R. and T. Robert Fisher, 1996.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Box 64 contains audiovisual material. Restricted fragile material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence from publishers McGraw-Hill and Harper & Brothers

scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence from publisher Alan Swallow, Opal Fisher correspondence, financial statements, and documents relating to the Vardis Fisher Memorial Fund

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence about Vardis Fisher, scripts for "Jeremiah Johnson", and a collection of western essays

scopecontent.p: Includes drafts of Fisher's manuscripts "Idaho Folklore", "Original Idaho Source Material", and "The Redwood", as well as galley proofs for "Orphans of Gethsemane"

scopecontent.p: Includes essays by Vardis Fisher about the "Testament of Man" series and other works, invoices from publishers, a published interview of Vardis Fisher, and newspaper clippings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence relating to Fisher's work, personal correspondence, drafts of Fisher's essay "The World's Greatest Physical Wonderland," and royalty statements

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence from Don and Thelma Lewis, newspaper clippings of articles by and about Vardis Fisher, and notecards Fisher used for his writings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Opal Fisher correspondence concerning Vardis Fisher's death, financial matters, submissions to publishers, and clippings relating to the film "Jeremiah Johnson"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Vardis Fisher correspondence, Opal Fisher correspondence concerning the Vardis Fisher memorial, photographs, and miscellaneous files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Opal Fisher correspondence to publishers, miscellaneous drafts, and financial records

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Opal Fisher correspondence to publishers and literary agencies, clippings of articles by Vardis Fisher, and copies of literary publications

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Opal Fisher correspondence pertaining to the Vardis Fisher Memorial Fund and photographs of the Fisher family
